Condition/Formula Name: Cancer General Support - Yu Ping Feng San Modified (Jade Windscreen with Anticancer Herbs)
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: How does TCM support cancer patients? A: TCM supports by boosting immunity, reducing treatment side effects, improving quality of life, and addressing underlying imbalances. Q: Can this be used for all ages? A: Yes, dosage adjusted for pediatric, adult, and elderly patients based on constitution and conventional treatment.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, LI4, LI11, BL20, BL21, CV12, GV14, BL17, CV4

Condition/Formula Name: Chemo-Induced Nausea/Vomiting - Xuan Fu Dai Zhe Tang Modified
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What does this treat in cancer patients? A: Nausea, vomiting, poor appetite during chemotherapy, particularly severe morning nausea. Q: What ages can use this? A: Safe for children (age 3+), adults, and elderly with dose modification; pediatric dose 1/4-1/2 adult dose.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: PC6, ST36, CV12, ST25, LI4, SP4, PC8, CV13

Condition/Formula Name: Chemo-Induced Bone Marrow Suppression - Dang Gui Bu Xue Tang + Huang Qi
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What does this formula address? A: Leukopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia following chemotherapy by tonifying Qi and Blood to support bone marrow recovery. Q: Is this safe for children with cancer? A: Yes, widely used in pediatric oncology with appropriate dosing; combines well with G-CSF when needed.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, BL20, BL17, CV4, CV6, GV4, LI11
Pharmacopeia: Chinese Pharmacopoeia 2020, Pediatric Oncology TCM Protocols

Condition/Formula Name: Chemo-Induced Peripheral Neuropathy - Huang Qi Gui Zhi Wu Wu Tang
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What syndrome does this treat? A: Numbness, tingling, pain in hands and feet from chemotherapy drugs (especially platinum-based and taxanes). Q: What is the mechanism? A: Warms channels, nourishes Blood, improves circulation to peripheral nerves, reduces oxidative nerve damage.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LI4, LI11, ST36, SP6, GB34, BL40, SI3, BL62

Condition/Formula Name: Chemo Brain Fog/Fatigue - Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang Modified
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What does this address? A: Post-chemotherapy fatigue, cognitive impairment ('chemo brain'), poor concentration, memory issues. Q: How long should it be used? A: Can be used throughout treatment and recovery phase; improves mental clarity and energy within 2-4 weeks.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: GV20, GV24, ST36, CV12, CV6, BL20, PC6, HT7

Condition/Formula Name: Radiation-Induced Dry Mouth (Xerostomia) - Sha Shen Mai Dong Tang
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What condition does this treat? A: Severe dry mouth from head/neck radiation causing difficulty swallowing, speaking, tooth decay. Q: Does it help saliva production? A: Yes, nourishes Yin, generates fluids, stimulates salivary glands; often combined with acupuncture for best results.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LI4, ST36, KI6, LU7, CV24, ST6, LI18, CV23

Condition/Formula Name: Radiation Burns/Skin Damage - Qing Ying Tang + External Applications
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What does this treat? A: Radiation dermatitis, burns, skin inflammation from radiotherapy treatment fields. Q: Can this be used externally? A: Yes, internal decoction plus external wash/compress with herbs like Di Yu, Huang Lian, Bai Ji reduces inflammation and promotes healing.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LI4, LI11, SP10, BL17, GB21, local points around affected area

Condition/Formula Name: Radiation-Induced Lung Injury (Pneumonitis) - Mai Men Dong Tang + Bei Sha Shen
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What pattern does this address? A: Dry cough, shortness of breath, chest tightness from radiation to chest causing lung inflammation. Q: When should this be started? A: Can be used preventatively during radiation and for treatment of acute/chronic radiation pneumonitis.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LU1, LU5, LU9, CV17, BL13, ST36, KI6, CV22

Condition/Formula Name: Lung Cancer Support - Yangzheng Xiaoji Capsule
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What evidence supports this for lung cancer? A: Randomized controlled trials show 23.3% vs 14% response rate when combined with chemotherapy, reduces bone marrow suppression. Q: What does it do? A: Tonifies Qi, resolves phlegm, softens hardness, inhibits cancer cell adhesion/migration, reduces angiogenesis.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LU1, LU5, LU7, CV17, BL13, ST36, ST40, CV12

Condition/Formula Name: Breast Cancer Support - Xiao Yao San + Xia Ku Cao + Chuan Shan Jia
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What does this formula treat? A: Breast cancer with Liver Qi stagnation causing breast masses, pain, emotional stress, irregular menses. Q: Can this be used with hormone therapy? A: Yes, but avoid strongly estrogenic herbs; focus on Qi-regulating and Blood-invigorating herbs; consult oncologist.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LR3, GB34, CV17, ST18, SP6, PC6, LR14, SI1
Pharmacopeia: Chinese Pharmacopoeia 2020, Breast Cancer Integrative Care

Condition/Formula Name: Liver Cancer (HCC) Support - Hua Chan Su + Radix Astragali Formula
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: What is Hua Chan Su? A: Toad venom extract with bufadienolides; induces apoptosis in liver cancer cells, inhibits growth. Q: What are the risks? A: Can cause cardiac toxicity at high doses; requires professional monitoring; improves performance status in HCC patients.
TCM Trigger Acupuncture Points: LR3, LR14, GB34, BL18, BL19, ST36, SP6, CV12

Condition/Formula Name: Colorectal Cancer - Bai Hua She She Cao + Ban Zhi Lian + FOLFOX Support
Q&A (Questions and Answers): Q: How does this support colorectal cancer treatment? A: Used with FOLFOX chemotherapy; improves tumor response, reduces neutropenia, nausea, neurotoxicity. Q: What are the key herbs? A: Bai Hua She She Cao (Oldenlandia) and Ban Zhi Lian (Scutellaria barbata) have anti-tumor properties.
